modules.description: This module provides functions to retrieve and format carbon intensity data for specific time periods, including forecasted and actual values measured in grams of CO2 per kilowatt-hour. It works with a custom type `t` representing carbon intensity information and an enumerated `index` type that classifies intensity levels. Concrete use cases include displaying carbon intensity forecasts for energy usage planning and comparing actual emissions data against predictions for grid regions.

The module provides functions to retrieve and calculate carbon intensity factors for energy grids, specifically working with kilowatt-hour (kWh) energy usage values and geographic location data. It supports concrete use cases such as determining the CO2-eq emissions for a given energy consumption in a specific region, and comparing emissions across different geographic areas based on grid carbon intensity.

This module provides functions to retrieve the current carbon intensity in grams of CO₂-equivalent per kilowatt-hour (gCO₂/kWh) for the French energy grid. It works with a dedicated type `t` representing the French grid data and exposes the `get_intensity` function to fetch the latest intensity value. A concrete use case is determining the environmental impact of electricity consumption in real-time for applications optimizing energy usage based on carbon output.

This module defines constants and types representing geographic zones (countries and sub-regions like states, provinces, or utility areas) for carbon intensity data retrieval via the Electric Map API. The `Zone.t` type encapsulates predefined identifiers such as country codes (e.g., `bt` for Bhutan) and regional subdivisions (e.g., `ca_ab` for Alberta, Canada), enabling precise location-based queries for CO2 emissions tracking. Functions also support string serialization and deserialization, facilitating integration with API requests and energy data analysis workflows.

This module provides the `get_intensity` function to retrieve the current carbon intensity value in grams of CO₂ equivalent per kilowatt-hour (gCO₂/kWh), if available. It operates on a value of type `t`, which represents a carbon intensity signal. A concrete use case is querying real-time grid carbon intensity data to optimize energy usage based on environmental impact.

This module represents carbon intensity data for energy grids, providing access to CO2-eq values in grams per kilowatt-hour, associated geographic zones, and timestamps. It includes functions to retrieve the intensity value, its corresponding zone, and the datetime when the data was recorded. This data is used to determine the environmental impact of energy consumption in specific regions at specific times.

This module represents a time interval during which carbon intensity data is valid, using ISO8601-formatted strings for the start and end timestamps. It provides functions to extract the beginning and end of the period from a `t` value. This module is used to handle time ranges returned by the Carbon API for energy grid emissions data in the UK.

This module provides functions to retrieve the current carbon intensity of the UK grid in grams of CO₂ equivalent per kilowatt-hour. It works with a `t` type representing grid intensity data, obtained via integration with UK-specific energy APIs. A concrete use case is determining the optimal time to run energy-intensive tasks based on real-time grid emissions.

This module defines an error type for handling API-related failures when querying carbon intensity data. It provides functions to create, compare, and convert error values into human-readable strings or JSON. These operations are used when validating API responses or handling network issues during carbon intensity lookups.

This module provides functions to retrieve real-time carbon intensity data for specific geographic zones using the Electric Map API. It works with zone identifiers and returns intensity values in grams of CO₂-eq per kilowatt-hour, along with associated metadata like timestamps and region information. Concrete use cases include querying current emissions data for a region to optimize energy usage timing or calculate the environmental impact of electricity consumption.

This module provides functions to retrieve real-time carbon intensity data for energy grids in France, returning values in grams of CO₂ equivalent per kilowatt-hour. It works with a configuration type `t` that encapsulates network access. Concrete use cases include optimizing energy usage timing based on grid cleanliness and integrating carbon impact data into energy monitoring applications.

This module provides functions to retrieve and work with real-time carbon intensity data in grams of CO₂-equivalent per kilowatt-hour (gCO₂/kWh) for specific regional energy grids. It defines and uses the `t` type to represent grid-specific carbon intensity values, enabling precise queries and comparisons. Concrete use cases include optimizing the timing of energy-intensive processes based on current grid emissions and assessing the environmental impact of electricity usage in real time.

This module provides functions to query carbon intensity data for the UK energy grid, including current, historical, and forecasted values measured in grams of CO2 per kilowatt-hour. It supports retrieving intensity data for specific time intervals using ISO8601 timestamps and calculating emissions based on energy consumption and geographic location. Concrete use cases include optimizing energy usage timing based on carbon intensity forecasts and calculating CO2-eq emissions for specific energy consumption patterns in the UK.

This module provides functions to query real-time, historical, and forecasted carbon intensity data for energy grids in the UK, France, and other regions via zone identifiers. It works with timestamps, geographic locations, and energy consumption values to calculate CO₂-eq emissions and support decision-making for energy usage timing. Concrete use cases include adjusting when energy-intensive tasks run based on grid cleanliness and calculating the environmental impact of electricity consumption in specific regions.
